üßµ2/2

Uh-oh. There‚Äôs a funny thing about that insane experiment being conducted by our rulers.

Although many scientists have done their best to warn what could happen if such reckless burning of fossil fuels didn‚Äôt stop, it turns out now that those scientists might not have fully understood all that was happening.

It seems their models were not good enough. The problem, you see, is even more difficult than they realized‚Ä¶
___________________________________

Fifty years into the project of modeling Earth‚Äôs future climate, we still don‚Äôt really know what‚Äôs coming. Some places are warming with more ferocity than expected. Extreme events are taking scientists by surprise.

Right now, as the bald reality of climate change bears down on human life, scientists are seeing more clearly the limits of our ability to predict the exact future we face. The coming decades may be far worse, and far weirder, than the best models anticipated.

Some variables are missing from climate models entirely. Trees and land are major sinks for carbon emissions, and that this fact might change is not accounted for in climate models. But it is changing: Trees and land absorbed much less carbon than normal in 2023, according to research published last October. In Finland, forests have stopped absorbing the majority of the carbon they once did, and recently became a net source of emissions.

The interactions of the ice sheets with the oceans are also largely missing from models, despite the fact that melting ice could change ocean temperatures which could have significant knock-on effects. Changing ocean-temperature patterns are currently making climate modelers at NOAA rethink their models of El Ni√±o and La Ni√±a; the agency initially predicted that La Ni√±a‚Äôs cooling powers would kick in much sooner than it now appears they will.

While models struggle to capture the world we live in now, the planet is growing more alien to us, further from our reference ranges, as the climate keeps changing. If given unlimited time, science could probably develop models that more fully captured what we‚Äôre watching play out. But by then it would be too late to do anything about it.
___________________________________

White House presser re LA fires:

President Biden said the federal government will cover 100% of the cost of recovery efforts for the next 180 days.

He said Cal Fire, because DWP cut power to their pumping systems, is purchasing backup power supplies for these.

The federal government, alongside Canada, is sending additional help to California.

"We are with you."

"Firefighters and first responders really are heroes."

POTUS gave a nod to reporters covering the fires.

VP Harris is speaking now. "Sadly, insurance companies have cancelled insurance on many of these families ... who will not have the resources to recover in any meaningful way." She praises neighbors helping neighbors. She calls the firefighters heroes.

POTUS is speaking again. He talks about how the US Forest Service is helping. Now to the fire chief.

4 major fires going on in California. Eaton, Hurst, Hamlet, and Palisades. "We're normally at the lowest point of fire in the year." Spoke of climate changing. Said winds kept flying support grounded. "In the last 24 hours, we've had 50 starts." "We stopped the potential for 50 additional fires." Says POTUS did an excellent job of summarizing where we are, so he won't go over that. Talks about air tankers. There are 8 of them. They will have all 8 available soon. [At this time of year, nothing was going on before billionaires decided to become gods, so they did maintenance now. Rushing to get them into service, along with support planes.] "We are going to monitor the air space" because it is "tight," and briefly notes having to avoid drones. Each fire will be investigated. "It would be unusual for lighting-caused fires at this time of year."

POTUS asks what is most concerning now. Chief says wind. Talks about how the winds in the morning blow in one direction, then change directions in the afternoon, making it more difficult.

Talking about recovery now. Mental health support included. Circled back to insurance companies cutting policies. Feds in discussion with state and local governments about how to provide temp housing and other support. Talking about support for hazardous materials removal, and rebuilding smartly. Thinks the mental health stress will be a significant issue. Again took swipes at insurance companies.

POTUS says church and school rebuilding is part of his declaration. Asked if hazardous material removal will take some time. Yes, it will. 360,000 people have been evacuated so far.

The fire administrator for FEMA is on the line. She has been with gov & fire chiefs. On the ground. Checking on firefighters on the front line. They are exhausted. They can take a quick nap in the truck sometimes. Thinks it's important that FEMA shows up & lets them know they're there. "There is so much work firefighters are doing beyond fire suppression." Plan to be there for a couple of more days.

POTUS mentions mental health issues. Pivots to Department of Defense. They have been in receipt of requests. [DOD-speak for we're trying to help.]

Chairman Brown says they have 500,000 available to support, but not in firefighting operations because they'd need training. Search & response, medical care, and other support. Notes some California NG have firefighting training and will be added. C-130's to drop water or retardant. 2 of them on the Channel Islands. More tomorrow. Flights begin tomorrow.

card.title: Flood modeling prior to the instrumental era reveals limited magnitude of 1931 Yangtze flood - npj Climate and Atmospheric Science
card.description: The global flood risk urges an improved understanding of flood magnitude and its mechanism, which needs insights from pre-instrumental flood investigations. Due to data scarcity, reconstructing pre-instrumental flood magnitudes relies on statistical downscaling, failing to capture nonlinear and dynamic characteristics. We developed a dynamical approach, NorESM-WRF-SWAT, integrating a global climate, a regional, and a hydrologic model to investigate the 1931 Yangtze River flood (the deadliest in the world) and compared it with the 1998‚Äôs. Through validation, our method outperforms the statistical method in simulating precipitations and river discharges. For the first time, we presented detailed insights into the intensity and duration of the 1931 flood, revealing a smaller magnitude but associated with an amplified loss, likely due to social vulnerability and reduced societal resilience compared to the 1998‚Äôs. While successful simulation can be interfered with by model variability, our dynamical method shows promise for simulating pre-instrumental flood and building a long-term pre-instrumental-hydrology database.

e Several ‚Äúgeoengineering‚Äù concepts proposed for the polar regions fail to meet essential criteria to be considered responsible approaches towards limiting the escalation of climate-related risks, including feasibility and likelihood of success.

e Polar geoengineering would cause severe environmental damage and comes with the possibility of grave unforeseen consequences.

e Polar regions have complex environmental protection and governance frameworks, which will likely reject polar geoengineering research efforts and large-scale projects.

e Minimizing risk and damage from climate change is best achieved by mitigating the cause of climate harm through immediate, rapid and deep decarbonization, rather than attempting interventions in fragile polar ecosystems.
